questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 2:1-20 aloud, focusing on the contrast between the Jewish tradition of purification and the unexpected birth in a manger.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the city of David' (v.4, v.11)
Pay attention to the angel's declaration: 'Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace among those with whom he is pleased!' (v.14)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters for Gentile believers.
tips: Include the decree of Caesar Augustus requiring registration (v.1-2)
Note the birth in a manger because there was no room in the inn (v.6-7)
Simeon's prophecy about a light for Gentiles and glory for Israel (v.30)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the birth in the manger (v.6-7), the angel's announcement to shepherds (v.8-14), or Simeon's recognition (v.29-32).
tips: The manger setting: Jesus born to a poor family in a stable, highlighting humility and accessibility
The angel's message: 'Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace among those with whom he is pleased!' (v.14) - this speaks to both heavenly and earthly peace
Simeon's recognition: 'My eyes have seen your salvation that you have prepared in the presence of all peoples' (v.32) - shows the universal scope of salvation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus (a Gentile believer) about the birth of Jesus?
tips: Luke emphasizes Jesus as the fulfillment of prophecy (David's city, the Messiah) for all people, especially Gentiles
The birth story is designed to show that salvation is available to all ethnic groups through Jesus
This passage addresses the Gentile audience by demonstrating God's universal salvation plan

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The inn setting, the angelic visitation, or Simeon's role in the temple?
tips: Why was there no room in the inn? This reflects the social status of Jesus as a lowly birth, not a palace birth
The term 'Savior' (v.11) might be confusing because it's used for both Jesus and the Jewish people (the Messiah)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'salvation for all peoples' from this chapter this week?
tips: Consider how you can share the good news of Jesus with someone who is from a different background
Think about a way to be a 'light to the Gentiles' in your community by serving others
Pray for the peace that comes from being in God's will (v.14)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the birth of Jesus and the universal scope of salvation.
tips: Thank God for sending Jesus as a Savior for all peoples
Ask for the courage to share the gospel with people from different cultures
Pray for peace among those who are in God's will (v.14)

chapters.chapterTitle: John the Baptist and Jesus' Baptism

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 3:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the description of John's wilderness ministry and the baptism events.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'baptism of repentance' (v.3, 4)
Pay attention to the contrast between John's humility (v.16) and Jesus' divinity (v.22)
The phrase 'the voice of one crying in the wilderness' (v.4) is a direct quote from Isaiah

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO is preaching, WHAT they do, WHERE it happens, and WHY John's ministry is important.
tips: John the Baptist preaches repentance in the wilderness near the Jordan River
He calls people to be baptized for the forgiveness of sins (v.3)
John prepares the way for Jesus' ministry (v.4-5)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: John's declaration about Jesus (v.16-17), the baptism event (v.21-22), or the voice from heaven (v.22)?
tips: John's humility: 'he who is mightier than I is coming' (v.16) shows his focus on Jesus
The voice from heaven: 'You are my beloved Son; with you I am well pleased' (v.22) reveals the Trinity
Jesus' baptism at age 30 (v.22) marks the beginning of his public ministry

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/Gentile believers about the role of John the Baptist and Jesus' baptism?
tips: Luke emphasizes that John's ministry prepares the way for Jesus (the Messiah) as prophesied by Isaiah
The baptism of Jesus reveals the Trinity: the Holy Spirit descending, the Father's voice, and Jesus as the beloved Son
This passage shows that Jesus is the fulfillment of the Old Testament prophecies and the beginning of his public ministry

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'baptism of fire', the role of the Holy Spirit, or the timing of Jesus' ministry?
tips: 'Baptism of fire' (v.16) refers to the purifying effect of the Holy Spirit, not literal fire
The Holy Spirit descending on Jesus (v.22) is a unique event that shows Jesus' divinity
The phrase 'he who is mightier than I' (v.16) indicates John's recognition of Jesus' authority

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of preparation for Christ's coming in your life this week?
tips: Reflect on what you need to 'prepare' (repentance) for God's work in your life
Pray for the Holy Spirit to transform you like the 'baptism of fire'
Commit to a step of obedience that aligns with Jesus' coming (e.g., sharing your faith)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for Jesus as the beloved Son and for the Holy Spirit's work. Ask for the courage to repent and be baptized by the Spirit.
tips: Thank God for Jesus as the beloved Son and for the Holy Spirit's work
Ask for the courage to repent and be baptized by the Spirit
Pray for the guidance to see how Christ is preparing the way for you

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 4:1-30 aloud, focusing on the dialogue with the devil (vv. 3-4, 6-7) and the rejection in Nazareth (vv. 16-21).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'It is written' in verses 4 and 7
Pay attention to the emotional shift from Jesus' confidence to the crowd's rejection in verse 22

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jesus) is tested, WHAT (he was tempted by the devil for 40 days, then read in Nazareth and was rejected), WHERE (the wilderness and Nazareth), and WHY (to show that the Messiah is led by the Spirit and will be rejected in His hometown).
tips: Jesus' 40-day temptation in the wilderness (v. 1-3)
The devil's three temptations and Jesus' responses using Scripture (v. 3-4, 6-7)
Jesus' reading of Isaiah in Nazareth and the crowd's rejection (v. 16-21)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' use of Scripture to defeat the devil (v. 4, 7), his anointing by the Spirit (v. 18), or the crowd's reaction (v. 22).
tips: Jesus' immediate response to the devil's first temptation: 'It is written, man shall not live by bread alone' (v. 4) shows his reliance on God's Word, not human needs
The phrase 'No prophet is acceptable in his hometown' (v. 19) highlights the universal truth that the Messiah will be rejected by His own people
The scroll of Isaiah being read and fulfilled in that moment (v. 21) demonstrates the divine plan being realized

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/Gentile believers about Jesus' identity and mission?
tips: Luke emphasizes that Jesus is the anointed one (Messiah) who fulfills Isaiah's prophecy (v. 18-21), showing that His mission is to bring good news to the poor and liberty to captives
The rejection in Nazareth (v. 19-22) serves as a warning that the Messiah's work will face opposition, especially from those who know Him best
This passage prepares the Gentile audience for Jesus' future mission by showing that He is led by the Spirit (v. 1) and will be rejected by His own people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The 40-day temptation, the rejection in Nazareth, and the role of Scripture in defeating the devil.
tips: The 40-day temptation: This is a unique test of Jesus, but it's not a 'test' in the sense of trying to sin (as in the Old Testament) but rather a demonstration of His perfect obedience to God
The crowd's rejection: In Jewish context, a prophet is expected to be accepted in their hometown. This shows that Jesus' mission is not limited to the Jewish people but will face opposition from all
The devil's offer of kingdoms: The devil's power is to offer worldly power (v. 6-7), but Jesus counters with the command to worship God alone (v. 7)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does Jesus' use of Scripture to resist temptation apply to your life?
tips: When you face a temptation to do something that seems easy (like the devil's offer of bread), recall that God provides more than physical needs (v. 4)
Pray for the strength to use Scripture to resist temptation, just as Jesus did
This week, choose one area where you might need to 'read the Scripture' to guide your decisions

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's help in resisting temptation and understanding the rejection of Jesus in Nazareth.
tips: Thank God for Jesus' victory over the devil through Scripture
Pray for courage to stand firm in faith when facing opposition
Ask God to help you recognize devil's temptations and respond with Scripture

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 6:20-49 aloud, paying special attention to the contrast in the blessings and woes (vv. 20-23) and the call to love enemies (vv. 27-38).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'blessed' and 'woe' in the blessings section (vv. 20-23)
Pay attention to the phrase 'love your enemies' and the practical application in verses 27-38
Listen for the contrast between the 'log' in your eye and the 'speck' in your brother's eye (vv. 41-42)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Jesus addresses, WHAT he teaches, WHERE this happens (the level place), and WHY (to establish kingdom ethics for the early church).
tips: Include the poor, hungry, and the rich as the targets of the blessings and woes
Note the call to love enemies and the practical commands (e.g., 'do good to those who hate you')
Highlight the parable of the tree and fruit (vv. 43-45) as the final teaching

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the blessing on the poor (v. 20), the command to love enemies (v. 27-38), or the tree and fruit metaphor (v. 43-45)?
tips: The blessing on the poor (v. 20) is radical in a culture that values wealth and social status
The command to love enemies (v. 27-38) is a radical call that challenges the status quo of the time
The tree and fruit metaphor (v. 43-45) is a clear and concise way to show that true discipleship produces good fruit

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/Gentile believers about the nature of the kingdom of God and how it should be lived?
tips: Luke's audience (Gentile believers) needed to understand that the kingdom of God is characterized by radical love and humility, not worldly success
The sermon provides a blueprint for living as a disciple in a hostile world (e.g., Rome and Jewish authorities)
The call to love enemies and the mercy of God (vv. 36-38) shows that the kingdom of God is a community of grace that transcends social and ethnic divisions

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The blessing on the poor? Why love enemies? The tree and fruit metaphor?
tips: The blessing on the poor (v. 20) might seem counterintuitive in a culture that values wealth and social status
The command to love enemies (v. 27-38) is radical in a context where enemies were often physical threats (e.g., Roman soldiers, Jewish authorities)
The tree and fruit metaphor (v. 43-45) is a way to show that true discipleship is evident by their actions, not just words

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice loving your enemies this week? Consider the specific actions in Luke 6:27-38.
tips: Identify one person who has been an enemy to you (e.g., a person you've argued with) and try to do one good thing for them
Practice mercy by forgiving someone who has wronged you, even if it's small
Reflect on the 'log' in your own eye (v. 42) and how you might be ignoring your own faults when you judge others

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the call to love enemies and the mercy of God as shown in this passage.
tips: Thank God for the command to love enemies and the mercy that flows from the cross
Pray for the courage to forgive and do good to those who hate you
Ask God to help you see the 'log' in your own eye and to be more like the Father who is merciful

chapters.chapterTitle: Faith of the Centurion and Raising the Widow's Son

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 7:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the centurion's humility and the power of Jesus' word.
tips: Notice the centurion's words: 'I am not worthy to have you come under my roof'
Pay attention to the centurion's request: 'Say the word, and let my servant be healed'
Listen for the emotional shift as the widow's son is raised from death

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the centurion, his servant, the widow and her son) does WHAT (the centurion sends for Jesus to heal his servant, Jesus raises the widow's son from death), WHERE (Capernaum and Nain), and WHY (to demonstrate God's power and visitation to His people).
tips: Include the centurion's status as a Roman military officer (non-Jewish)
Note the widow's son was dead and raised by Jesus
Explain the centurion's faith in Jesus' word without requiring ritual

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the centurion's faith (v.1-10), the widow's son raised (v.11-17), or the centurion's humility?
tips: The centurion's words: 'Say the word, and let my servant be healed' shows his understanding of Christ's authority without religious rituals
The widow's son rising from death demonstrates God's visitation to His people
The centurion's status as a Gentile having greater faith than the Jewish people

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus (Gentile believers) about the nature of faith and God's power through this passage?
tips: The centurion, a Gentile, has greater faith than the Jewish people, showing that faith in Christ is not limited to ethnic groups
Christ's word has healing and resurrection power, accessible to all who believe
God's visitation to His people is through Jesus, who demonstrates His power to the world

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The centurion's faith? The widow's son being raised? Why does the centurion have greater faith?
tips: Centurion's faith: As a Roman officer, he was not part of the Jewish religious system but understood Jesus' authority without needing rituals
The raising of the dead: This was a sign of God's power and visitation, which was a radical demonstration of Christ's authority
Why the centurion has greater faith? Because he recognized Jesus' authority without requiring religious rituals (unlike the Jewish people who were focused on the law)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the centurion's faith to your life this week? What does it mean to trust Christ's word for healing?
tips: Consider a situation where you need to trust God's word without seeing immediate results
Think about how the centurion's humility (not wanting Jesus to enter his house) can be applied to your own faith
Practice speaking to God with the same confidence as the centurion: 'Say the word, and let my need be healed'

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the centurion's faith and the raising of the widow's son. Ask for courage to trust Christ's word.
tips: Thank God that He heals through the word of Jesus
Pray for the courage to trust in Christ's authority even when it's difficult
Ask God to show you where you need to have the centurion's faith

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 11:1-16 aloud, focusing on the disciples' request for prayer teaching and the woe statements.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Father' in the Lord's Prayer (v.2-4)
Pay attention to the emotional shift from teaching prayer (v.1-4) to the strong man analogy (v.17-20)
The phrase 'woe to you' (v.42-44) is a strong critique of religious hypocrisy

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize in your own words: WHO (Jesus and disciples), WHAT (teaching the Lord's Prayer and warnings), WHERE (Jesus was praying), and WHY (to equip disciples for prayer and warn against hypocrisy).
tips: Jesus teaches the Lord's Prayer (v.2-4)
The strong man analogy (v.17-20) explains Jesus' authority over Satan
The woe to the Pharisees (v.42-44) criticizes religious practice that neglects justice and love

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Lord's Prayer (v.2-4), the 'strong man' analogy (v.17-20), or the woe statements (v.42-44)?
tips: The Lord's Prayer is a model of humble prayer that acknowledges God's sovereignty
The 'strong man' (v.17) shows Jesus as the One who plunders Satan's kingdom
The woe statements (v.42-44) are a direct critique of the Pharisees' neglect of justice and love

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/Gentile believers through this passage?
tips: Luke emphasizes that Jesus is the model for prayer and the source of the Holy Spirit
He shows that Jesus is the One stronger than Satan (v.20) and thus the true authority
The passage warns Gentile believers against religious hypocrisy that neglects the heart of God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The accusation about Beelzebul? The 'strong man' analogy? The woe statements?
tips: The phrase 'Beelzebul' (v.15) is a name for Satan, and the accusation that Jesus casts out demons by him is a claim of Jesus' authority
The 'strong man' (v.17) is a metaphor for Satan guarding his kingdom, and Jesus as the 'stronger' man takes it
The woe statements (v.42-44) are a critique of the Pharisees for tithing but neglecting justice and love of God

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the Lord's Prayer (v.2-4) to your daily life this week?
tips: Pray for forgiveness of others as you pray for yourself
Ask God for daily provision and guidance in your specific needs
Practice the phrase 'lead us not into temptation' by seeking God's strength

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the Lord's Prayer and the warning against hypocrisy.
tips: Thank God for teaching us to pray in the Lord's Prayer
Ask for the Holy Spirit to help you pray effectively
Pray for courage to avoid the hypocrisy of the Pharisees

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 12:1-48 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between warnings (e.g., hypocrisy) and encouragement (e.g., 'fear not') in the discourse.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'Beware' in verses 1-2 and 7
Pay attention to the contrast between the rich fool's possessions (v.16-19) and the fleeting nature of life (v.20)
The emotional shift from warning to reassurance in verses 22-34

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Jesus is warning (disciples), WHAT they must beware of (hypocrisy, covetousness), WHERE this happens (a large crowd gathering), and WHY (to prepare for persecution and discipleship).
tips: The crowd gathering in the streets (v.1)
The disciples as the primary audience (v.1-2)
The context of persecution and the need for spiritual readiness (v.22-34)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the warning about hypocrisy (v.1-2), the acknowledgment of Christ (v.3-4), the rich fool parable (v.16-21), or the encouragement to fear not (v.22-34)?
tips: The rich fool parable (v.16-21) shows the contrast between worldly wealth and eternal life in a way that is relatable and cautionary
The phrase 'fear not, little flock' (v.31) provides immediate comfort and reassurance in the face of anxiety
The contrast between the rich man's possessions and his soul's requirement (v.20) highlights the fleeting nature of material wealth

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/Gentile believers about the challenges of discipleship in the early church?
tips: To emphasize that true discipleship requires humility and a focus on spiritual matters rather than worldly wealth
To prepare the Gentile believers for potential persecution by encouraging trust in God's provision
To show that Christ's acknowledgment is a sign of the kingdom, and that the Holy Spirit will guide in persecution

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? (e.g., the rich fool parable, the statement about being acknowledged by angels, the use of 'leaven' for hypocrisy)
tips: The term 'leaven of the Pharisees' (v.1) refers to hypocrisy that spreads and corrupts, not the actual leaven in bread
The phrase 'acknowledged before the angels of God' (v.3) means that Christ's followers will be recognized by heavenly authorities, not that angels will see them physically
The rich fool's story (v.16-21) is a parable that uses the contrast between the rich man's possessions and his soul's impermanence to show the danger of materialism

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of 'fear not' (v.22-34) and how it applies to your current anxiety about possessions and life.
tips: Identify one area where you are anxious about your possessions or life and ask God to show you how He will provide
Practice being 'dressed for action' (v.34) by keeping your spiritual life active and your lamps burning (e.g., prayer, service)
Reflect on the rich fool's story and consider what you can give up to focus on eternal life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of fear not and the kingdom of God.
tips: Thank God for His promise that He will provide for your needs (v.30-31)
Ask for courage to trust in His provision when facing financial or personal challenges
Pray that you will be 'little flocks' who are not anxious but focused on His kingdom

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 13:1-21 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of Jesus' lament for Jerusalem and the contrast between the barren fig tree and the freed woman.
tips: Note the repetition of 'unless you repent' in v.3 and v.5
Pay attention to the contrast between the Galileans' suffering and the call for repentance
The phrase 'O Jerusalem, Jerusalem' (v.34) carries deep sorrow and longing

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Jesus is speaking to, WHAT he says about repentance, WHERE this occurs, and WHY he uses the examples of the Galileans and the fig tree.
tips: The Galileans (v.1-5): A group of people who were killed by Roman authorities
The fig tree (v.6-9): Jesus' teaching on the need for fruitfulness in the kingdom
The crippled woman (v.12-13): Jesus healing on the Sabbath

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' warning about repentance (v.3), the fig tree parable (v.6-9), or the healing of the woman (v.12-13)?
tips: The call to repentance: 'Unless you repent, you will all likewise perish' (v.3) is a stark warning that applies universally
The fig tree: Jesus says the tree is barren and will be cut down if it doesn't bear fruit in the next year (v.7-9) - a picture of Israel's need for repentance
The healing of the woman: Jesus says 'Woman, you are freed from your disability' (v.13) - showing grace and compassion on the Sabbath

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/Gentile believers about the necessity of repentance and the narrow path to salvation?
tips: Luke's purpose was to show that salvation requires repentance and faith, not just religious rituals
The fig tree represents Israel's failure to produce spiritual fruit (the kingdom of God) and the need for a change of heart
The lament over Jerusalem shows that even the city that killed the prophets is not saved without repentance

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The Galileans' blood being mingled with sacrifices, the meaning of the fig tree, or the Sabbath healing?
tips: The Galileans' blood being mingled with sacrifices (v.1): This refers to the Roman soldiers killing Galileans and mixing their blood with the sacrifices that were being offered at the temple (a sign o
The fig tree (v.6-9): In Jewish tradition, the fig tree was a symbol of Israel and its failure to bear fruit (the kingdom of God) without repentance
Healing on the Sabbath (v.12-13): Jesus is challenging the religious leaders' interpretation of the Sabbath by healing a woman on the Sabbath day

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the call to repentance in your life this week? Consider the barren fig tree as a picture of your own spiritual state.
tips: Reflect on one area where you've been 'barren' (not producing spiritual fruit) and ask God for repentance
Commit to spending time in prayer and Scripture this week to 'bear fruit' (like the fig tree that is given time to produce)
Pray for the grace to heal the 'crippling spirit' in your life, just as Jesus did for the woman

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His mercy in the healing of the woman and ask for the courage to repent.
tips: Thank God for the example of Jesus healing the crippled woman on the Sabbath
Pray for the strength to repent of sins that keep you from bearing fruit
Ask Jesus to open your heart to the 'narrow door' of salvation

chapters.chapterTitle: Parables of the Banquet and Counting the Cost

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 14:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between Jesus' healing of the man with dropsy and the parable of the banquet.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'humble yourself' (v.11) and 'exalted' (v.12)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of Jesus' instruction: firm yet compassionate
The phrase 'count the cost' (v.26-27) appears in the context of discipleship

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jesus) is speaking to, WHAT (the parable of the banquet and the cost of discipleship), WHERE (at the house of a ruler of the Pharisees), and WHY (to challenge the guests' humility and the cost of following Christ).
tips: Include the healing of the man with dropsy (v.4) as a sign of Jesus' authority
Note the parable of the banquet: inviting the poor and marginalized (v.8-11)
Describe the call to count the cost of discipleship (v.26-27)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus healing the man with dropsy (v.4), the invitation to the low places (v.8), or the cost of discipleship (v.26-27)?
tips: The healing of the man with dropsy shows Jesus' compassion and authority over the Sabbath
The instruction to 'go and sit in the lowest place' (v.8) is a powerful call to humility
The phrase 'if anyone comes to me and does not hate...' (v.26-27) reveals the radical nature of discipleship

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/Gentile believers about the nature of discipleship and the kingdom of God through this passage?
tips: Luke emphasizes that true discipleship requires humility and a willingness to follow Jesus even at great cost (v.26-27)
The banquet parable shows that God's kingdom is filled by those who are marginalized and poor (v.8-11)
This passage addresses the Gentile believers by showing how they can participate in the kingdom through humility and costly obedience

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The call to 'humble yourself' (v.11), the requirement to 'count the cost' (v.26-27), or the idea of 'compelling' people to come (v.19-20)?
tips: 'Humble yourself' in v.11 is not about weakness but about selflessness and submission to God
The phrase 'count the cost' (v.26-27) is a radical call that may seem too costly for modern life
The instruction to 'compel people' (v.19-20) might be misinterpreted as aggressive rather than loving outreach

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice humility and count the cost of discipleship this week by inviting the marginalized and making sacrifices for others?
tips: Today, identify one person from your community who is poor or marginalized and reach out to them with kindness
Reflect on what you might need to 'humble' yourself in your relationships this week
Make a sacrifice for someone else, even if it's small (e.g., giving up a privilege to help another)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His grace in humbling us and empowering us to follow Him. Ask for courage to count the cost of discipleship.
tips: Thank God for the healing of the man with dropsy (v.4) and His compassion
Pray for humility in your own life and the courage to follow Jesus even when it's costly
Ask God to help you invite the poor and marginalized into your life this week

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 15:1-32 aloud, focusing on the emotional contrast between the Pharisees' grumbling and the joy of the parables.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'lost' and the joy in finding the one lost
Pay attention to the father's immediate response to the prodigal son (v.20)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jesus) does WHAT (tells three parables), WHERE (in the context of the crowds), and WHY (to illustrate the joy of repentance for the lost).
tips: Include the Pharisees' complaint about Jesus eating with sinners (v.1-2)
Note the three parables: lost sheep, lost coin, and prodigal son
Highlight the central theme: joy over one sinner who repents

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the father's running to embrace the prodigal (v.20), the prodigal's declaration 'I will arise and go to my father' (v.18), or the restoration language 'he was dead, and is alive again' (v.24).
tips: The father's running shows radical, uncalculated love that overcomes shame
The phrase 'he was dead, and is alive again' is a powerful metaphor for spiritual rebirth
The immediate embrace without conditions reflects God's grace

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/Gentile believers about God's active search for the lost and the joy in repentance?
tips: Luke writes for Gentile believers to emphasize that God's grace is for all, not just the Jewish people
The parables contrast the Pharisees' legalism with God's compassionate restoration
This shows that repentance and restoration are central to the gospel

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The contrast between 'righteous' and 'sinner', the spiritual death of the prodigal son, and the father's immediate action.
tips: The 'righteous' in v.7 are those who do not need repentance (like the Pharisees), not the morally perfect
Spiritual death means separation from God; the prodigal son's return is restoration
The father's running (v.20) shows God's love that is not conditional on the son's behavior

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you actively seek and restore relationships with those who are lost (spiritually) this week?
tips: Focus on one person in your life who is struggling and practice the father's compassion
Remember that God's joy comes in the restoration of the lost (v.7)
Pray for the courage to run to those who are lost, like the father

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the shepherd who seeks the lost and ask for the grace to run to those who are lost.
tips: Thank God for the joy of one sinner who repents (v.7)
Pray for courage to embrace the prodigal in your life
Ask God to strengthen your heart to seek and restore relationships

chapters.chapterTitle: The Shrewd Manager and the Rich Man and Lazarus

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 16:1-13 and 16:19-31 aloud, paying attention to the manager's shrewd actions and the contrast between the rich man and Lazarus.
tips: Notice the manager's phrase: 'I have decided what to do' (v. 2)
Pay attention to the rich man's complaint about Lazarus (v. 20-21)
Identify the emotional shift in the rich man's attitude (v. 24-25)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it takes place, and WHY it matters in the context of Luke 16.
tips: Include the shrewd manager's actions (v. 1-2) and the rich man's disregard for Lazarus (v. 19-21)
Note the setting: the rich man's house (v. 19) and the afterlife (v. 22-24)
Explain the cause: the rich man's neglect of the poor and Scripture (v. 31)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider the manager's shrewdness, the rich man's indifference, or the phrase 'Moses and the Prophets'?
tips: The manager's immediate action: 'I have decided what to do' (v. 2) shows quick thinking without waiting
The rich man's pride: 'He will be in torment' (v. 24) while Lazarus is in comfort (v. 22)
The phrase 'Moses and the Prophets' (v. 31) is a powerful call to heed Scripture

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/Gentile believers about the dangers of wealth and the importance of serving God?
tips: Luke addresses Gentile believers with a warning against wealth and the need for spiritual priorities
The shrewd manager foreshadows Christ as the ultimate 'manager' of our lives
The rich man and Lazarus story shows the consequences of ignoring the poor and Scripture

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The manager's dishonesty, the rich man's punishment, or the meaning of 'Moses and the Prophets'?
tips: The manager's shrewdness is practical but not moral: he is 'dishonest' yet commended (v. 8)
The rich man's punishment is for neglecting the poor and Scripture (v. 31)
The phrase 'Moses and the Prophets' (v. 31) refers to Old Testament teachings but points to Christ

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lesson that you cannot serve God and money (v. 13) this week?
tips: Identify an area where you use money to control your life (e.g., debt, materialism) and shift focus to God
Pray for the strength to be generous like the manager's actions but with integrity (v. 8)
Ask God to help you see the poor (Lazarus) in your community and serve them

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the warning about wealth and ask for the courage to prioritize Him over money.
tips: Thank God that He is the true manager of our lives (v. 13)
Pray for the grace to be generous and see the poor in your community
Ask God to help you heed Scripture (Moses and the Prophets) and not ignore warnings

chapters.chapterTitle: Faith, Duty, and the Coming Kingdom

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 17:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the high expectations of faith and the humility of serving.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'if he repents' (v.4) and 'seven times' (v.4)
Pay attention to the mustard seed faith (v.6) and the servant analogy (v.7-10)
The lepers incident (v.11-19) shows the contrast between the ten and the one who returns

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being taught, WHAT they are commanded to do, WHERE the teaching occurs, and WHY it matters for the early church.
tips: Include the apostles' request for faith (v.6)
Note the lepers' healing and the one who returns (v.11-19)
The kingdom of God statement (v.20-21)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the mustard seed faith (v.6), the servant analogy (v.7-10), or the lepers incident (v.11-19)?
tips: The mustard seed faith is a powerful image of small faith doing great things (v.6)
The servant analogy shows humility in doing what is expected (v.7-10)
The lepers incident highlights gratitude and the one who returns to praise God (v.11-19)

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/Gentile believers about faith, duty, and the coming kingdom?
tips: Luke emphasizes that true faith is active and humble (as in the servant analogy)
The kingdom of God is present in the midst of believers, not a future event
The focus on forgiveness and repeated repentance addresses the practical challenges of community life

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The 'seven times' forgiveness, the mustard seed faith, or the kingdom of God being 'in the midst of you'?
tips: The 'seven times' forgiveness (v.4) is a hyperbolic expression for complete forgiveness in the context of community
Mustard seed faith (v.6) is a metaphor for the power of small but faithful actions
The kingdom of God being 'in the midst of you' (v.21) challenges the expectation of a visible, external kingdom

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice the servant's duty and the spirit of forgiveness in your community this week?
tips: When someone repents, forgive them as you have been forgiven (v.4)
Reflect on what  you have done that was 'duty' (like serving) and what you can do better
Pray for the grace to forgive repeatedly

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for the kingdom of grace that is in the midst of us, and ask for the humility to serve and forgive.
tips: Thank God for the example of the one leper who returned to praise (v.18)
Pray for the courage to forgive repeatedly (v.4)
Ask for the faith to do what is small but powerful (v.6)

chapters.chapterTitle: Authority Challenged and the Wicked Tenants

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 20:9-26 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Jesus and the chief priests in verses 9-10 and the parable in verses 10-19.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'by what authority' in verse 9
Pay attention to the emotional tone of the tenants in the parable (verses 11-18) as they reject the owner
The phrase 'the stone that the builders rejected' (v.17) is a key reference to Christ

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is challenged, WHAT Jesus does, WHERE it happens, and WHY the chief priests are concerned.
tips: Include the chief priests and scribes challenging Jesus' authority (v.9)
Note the parable of the tenants (v.10-19) where the tenants reject the owner's servants and the son
Describe the tribute question (v.20-26) where Jesus asks for a denarius

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the parable of the tenants (v.10-19), the tenants' rejection of the son (v.12-13), or the tribute answer (v.24-26)?
tips: The tenants' decision to kill the son (v.12) mirrors the religious leaders' rejection of Christ
The phrase 'the stone that the builders rejected' (v.17) is a direct reference to Christ becoming the cornerstone
The tribute answer: 'Render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and to God the things that are God's' (v.24-26) is a profound statement of dual allegiance

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/Gentile believers about authority and faith through this passage?
tips: Luke emphasizes that Christ's authority comes from God, not human institutions (v.17)
The parable shows that the religious leaders (tenants) have rejected Christ, who is the cornerstone of the church
The tribute answer demonstrates that believers must honor both earthly and heavenly authorities

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The parable's meaning, the tenants' role, or the tribute question?
tips: The 'tenants' represent the religious leaders who have rejected God's authority (v.10-19) - this is a direct reference to the religious leaders of Jesus' time
The phrase 'the stone that the builders rejected' (v.17) is a reference to Christ being the cornerstone of the church, which may be confusing without context
The tribute question (v.20-26) challenges the idea that believers must obey Caesar (the Roman emperor) without also obeying God

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lesson of 'render to Caesar and to God' in your life this week?
tips: Consider a task that is 'Caesar's' (earthly) that you can do without compromising your faith
Think about how you can 'render to God' (spiritual) in a practical way
Pray for the courage to make decisions that honor both God and society

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His authority and ask for the courage to follow His lead.
tips: Thank God that He has given us the authority to live by His word (v.24)
Ask for the strength to reject the 'wicked tenants' of worldly authority
Pray for the grace to 'render to God the things that are God's' in your daily life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 21:1-24 aloud, focusing on the contrast between the widow's offering and the temple destruction prophecy.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'more' (v.4) and 'this poor widow has put in more than all of them' (v.4)
Pay attention to the shift in tone from the widow's generosity to the impending destruction of Jerusalem (v.5-6)
Listen for the phrase 'the Son of Man' (v.27) as the coming event

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jesus, the rich, the poor widow, the crowd) does WHAT (gives offerings, prophesies destruction), WHERE (the temple in Jerusalem), and WHY (to teach about true worship and the end times).
tips: Include the widow's two copper coins (v.1-4)
Note the temple's destruction in 70 AD (v.5-6)
Describe the signs of the end (v.7-24)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the widow's two coins (v.1-4), the temple destruction (v.5-6), or the Son of Man coming in glory (v.27).
tips: The widow's two coins show total devotion despite poverty (v.1-4)
The phrase 'one stone upon another' (v.5) is a vivid image of complete destruction
The Son of Man coming in a cloud (v.27) is the climax of the end times

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/Gentile believers about the end times and true worship?
tips: Luke emphasizes that Jesus is the fulfillment of prophecy and the only true worship
He warns against false teachers and persecution, but also promises His return
The widow's example shows that true worship is from the heart, not wealth

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The temple destruction prophecy? The signs in the sky? The Son of Man's return?
tips: The temple destruction (v.5-6) refers to the 70 AD destruction by Roman armies, which was a fulfillment of prophecy
The 'signs in sun and moon and stars' (v.10) are a sign of the end times, but the exact meaning is not specified in the text
The phrase 'the Son of Man' (v.27) is a title for Jesus that emphasizes His authority and coming judgment

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Like the widow, what can you give completely this week without worrying about your financial situation?
tips: Consider giving a small amount of your time or resources that you would normally save
Reflect on how you can trust God's provision when you are in a situation of scarcity
Practice giving without counting the cost, like the widow

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the courage to give like the widow and for the strength to endure persecution.
tips: Thank God for the widow's example of total giving
Ask for the grace to trust Him in difficult circumstances
Pray for the courage to be a witness in your community

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Luke 22:14-46 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue about the Last Supper and the prayer in Gethsemane.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'not my will, but yours, be done' (v.42)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of Jesus' prayer (v.42-44)
Notice the description of sweat like blood (v.44)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY Jesus is in Gethsemane.
tips: Include the institution of the new covenant (bread and wine) by Jesus
Note Jesus' prayer in Gethsemane (v.42-44)
Describe the betrayal by Judas (v.47-48)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the institution of the new covenant (v.19-20), Jesus' statement about serving (v.27), or the prayer in Gethsemane (v.42)?
tips: The new covenant in blood is a profound promise of forgiveness and new life
Jesus' statement 'I am among you as the one who serves' challenges the disciples' expectations of leadership
The prayer in Gethsemane shows Jesus' deep submission to the Father's will

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/Gentile believers about Christ's ultimate submission and the new covenant?
tips: Luke emphasizes Christ's role as the servant who establishes the new covenant through His death
The new covenant in blood (v.20) is a fulfillment of the Old Testament promises
This passage shows Christ's willingness to submit to the Father's will despite the cost

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The new covenant in blood (v.20), the sweat like blood (v.44), or the betrayal by Judas (v.47-48)?
tips: The new covenant refers to Christ's blood replacing animal sacrifices for forgiveness of sins
The sweat 'like blood' is a metaphor for intense spiritual distress (as in 1 Samuel 2:23)
Judas' betrayal was a fulfillment of Christ's prediction (v.21) and part of God's plan for the atonement

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice Christ's submission to God's will this week, especially in the area of the new covenant?
tips: Choose one area where you feel called to submit to God's will (like Jesus in Gethsemane)
Pray with the same resolve as Jesus: 'Not my will, but yours, be done'
Consider what it means to be 'the one who serves' in your daily life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the new covenant in His blood and ask for the strength to submit to His will.
tips: Thank God for the new covenant in Jesus' blood (v.20)
Pray for the courage to submit to God's will when it's difficult (like Jesus in Gethsemane)
Ask God to strengthen your faith in His promises
